Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Introducing Hierarchical Architectures into Advanced Functional Organic Materials Controlling the Secondary and Tertiary Structure of Carbon Nanocoils
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Macromolecular, Supramolecular, and Nanochemistry Program of the Division of Chemistry, Professor Felix Fischer of the University of California at Berkley is developing new synthetic polymers that can mimic the diverse structural features of naturally occurring biological polymers. Polymers are long chain organic molecules and are found in many facets of everyday life, and while synthetic polymers have been adapted to almost every aspect of our industrialized culture, their performance and structural diversity still falls short when compared to their biological analogues. The diversity both in architecture and function emerging from biological polymers ranges from molecular machinery, data and energy storage, to structural support that spans over several orders of magnitude, e.g. from the size of a sugar molecule (tiny fractions of a millimeter) to the height of a Sequoia tree (greater than 100 meters). The educational activities being pursued include the education and training of undergraduate and graduate students, establishing a "Girls Day" at the College of Chemistry at UC Berkeley, and participating in the "Touch a Molecule" program as a content contributor and a mentor.

In this project, Professor Fischer is developing new synthetic tools to encode higher order structure and complex function into artificial polymers with the goal of tuning both their physical properties (e.g. size, shape, electronic structure) and function (chemical reactivity or response to external stimuli) at the molecular scale and controlling both their programmed assembly and their cooperative interaction in precisely defined higher order architectures. Specifically, Professor Fischer is synthesizing poly(arylene ethynylenes) (PAEs) and "carbon nanocoils" using a relatively new polymerization methodology: ring-opening alkyne metathesis (ROAMP). The experimental plans includes exploring methodology to synthesize ring-strained monomers to access ortho-, meta-, and para-substituted PAEs, to develop molybdenum alkylidyne catalysts that well effect a living polymerization of the monomers, to study the conformational folding and secondary structures of the resultant PAEs, and to direct their further self-assembly.

Institution.Name: University of California-Berkeley
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA, THE

POR.DRECONTENT:
As part of this NSF CAREER award we have successfully developed a new class of polymerization reaction, a living ring opening alkyne metathesis (ROAMP), that enables unprecedented control over the synthesis and the self-assembly of functionalized, fully-conjugated semiconducting polymers derived from ortho- and meta-substituted poly-(arylene ethynylene). We developed the facile and scalable synthesis of ring-strained monomers that serve as the feedstock for the polymerization reaction and designed and tested second and third generation ring-opening alkyne metathesis polymerization catalysts derived from molybdenum complexes. A detailed mechanistic investigation provided valuable insight into the mechanism and the critical rates of reaction associated with the catalyst initiation, propagation, and termination kinetics. The optimization of all three reaction parameters enabled the realization of a living polymerization that gives absolute control over the average polymer chain length, weight distribution, and functional groups at either end of the chain. We further demonstrated that the ROAMP is compatible with a wide variety of existing radical-based living polymerizations and can be seamlessly integrated to access functional di- and triblock copolymers. Lastly, we expanded the scope of the reaction by using living ROAMP polymers as a template for the controlled synthesis of graphene nanoribbons, a functional one-dimensional strip of carbon that could one day replace silicon as the preferred material in the manufacture of integrated electronic circuit architectures.

Through an extensive outreach program in close collaboration with the Department of Chemistry at California State University East Bay, a primary undergraduate institution that serves >70% underrepresented minorities, we have hosted and trained five undergraduate students as summer researchers in our lab. We have successfully mentored each of them through their graduate school applications to the Departments of Chemistry at the University of Indiana, Cornell, and Northwestern.


Last Modified: 10/29/2020
Modified by: Felix R Fischer
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: As part of this NSF CAREER award we have successfully developed a new class of polymerization reaction, a living ring opening alkyne metathesis (ROAMP), that enables unprecedented control over the synthesis and the self-assembly of functionalized, fully-conjugated semiconducting polymers derived from ortho- and meta-substituted poly-(arylene ethynylene). We developed the facile and scalable synthesis of ring-strained monomers that serve as the feedstock for the polymerization reaction and designed and tested second and third generation ring-opening alkyne metathesis polymerization catalysts derived from molybdenum complexes. A detailed mechanistic investigation provided valuable insight into the mechanism and the critical rates of reaction associated with the catalyst initiation, propagation, and termination kinetics. The optimization of all three reaction parameters enabled the realization of a living polymerization that gives absolute control over the average polymer chain length, weight distribution, and functional groups at either end of the chain. We further demonstrated that the ROAMP is compatible with a wide variety of existing radical-based living polymerizations and can be seamlessly integrated to access functional di- and triblock copolymers. Lastly, we expanded the scope of the reaction by using living ROAMP polymers as a template for the controlled synthesis of graphene nanoribbons, a functional one-dimensional strip of carbon that could one day replace silicon as the preferred material in the manufacture of integrated electronic circuit architectures. Through an extensive outreach program in close collaboration with the Department of Chemistry at California State University East Bay, a primary undergraduate institution that serves >70% underrepresented minorities, we have hosted and trained five undergraduate students as summer researchers in our lab. We have successfully mentored each of them through their graduate school applications to the Departments of Chemistry at the University of Indiana, Cornell, and Northwestern.
